live virtual seminar

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
This course was extremely informative and helpful for a number of reasons. The syllabus is designed to give you a very full breadth of knowledge about the EU; its structure, its problems, its individual nations, its history. Each week is a new, well-chosen reading that contributes to this deep understanding. Professor Cameron is wonderful and structures the week around page-long, memo-like reflections on the assigned reading, points around which he will base the weeks discussion. 

Sitting in class is the most informative part though of course, and Professor Cameron always starts with an application of the reading to the current EUs happenings, cross-applying the theoretical and historical approach of the reading to the real life events.
In this course I learned a general overview of the significant components of the European Union. We discussed its origins, structure, and challenges it faces.
I learned about the European Union, including a mix of contemporary EU politics and political history. I also learned how to write a research prospectus.
deeper understanding of the European Union and all it's intricacies such as the single-market, goal of a European Identity, membership, etc.
Understanding of the EU's creation and systems management

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The courses strengths are in its structure. It is well-thought and the readings have a purpose. They are not randomly jiggsawed together, they have a real order and meaning. Professor Cameron is a strength of the course. His knowledge of the EU is endless and he facilitates discussion very well.

The weaknesses of the course are few- perhaps one being the monotony of a seminar-style class on Zoom. There were no visuals, no hands on experiences, of course, so from that standpoint, the experience was a bit monotonous, and yet still very interesting.

Strengths: The organization of this course is really conducive to building a great understanding of the European Union. Additionally, Professor Cameron is super great. Weaknesses: This course has a lot of required reading (roughly a book a week) and while the reading was very helpful in teaching concepts, I wonder if it could have been cut down a bit.

One strength of this course is its organization; I liked the discussion of a different theme each week. I also thought the workload was fair and evenly distributed; just a weekly response, and a research prospectus due at the end of the semester. 
One weakness of the course is that the discussion is really shaped by the other students' familiarity with the topics being discussed and willingness to engage. There were times when the discussion was slow.

Seminar was pretty good, though Professor Cameron did go off on tangents sometimes. I think I would have benefitted from some more discussion in the beginning of the semester of the basic governance structure of the EU. It's pretty complicated, and some discussion in class that reinforced the readings on the topic would have been helpful.

Discussion in each seminar was very informational and helpful in my understanding, but the reading load can be a lot most of the time. It is very easy for the discussion to become dominated by one or two students.

Strengths: information is comprehensive

Weaknesses: only two forms of informational input, books and articles. Could benefit from other modes of learning such as podcasts

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Cameron is not 100% with technology but he is such a caring human being and he always tries his best. Seminars work pretty well over Zoom, and discussion was facilitated well by Professor.
I thought the course worked well as a virtual seminar.
This class was basically a normal seminar, just on Zoom. It's a less enjoyable format, but it was fine.

Discussions were generally lively but there were still moments of awkward silence when no one had a point to offer. It was also very easy to have zoom burn-out from simply looking at everyone's screens for two hours without anything else like a slide/video, or even screen share to look at. Also we ran into technical difficulties a few times simply because the professor was not very technologically adept but there was not TA to provide assistance whenever those issues arrived. We sometimes had to emailing our professor in the zoom call if their volume was shut off or interrupting them to let them know students were in the waiting room because the professor could not always see our screens if we were raising our hands.
Normal seminar style

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: 100% recommend for someone interested in political science, Europe, or wants to take a well-designed class with a very knowledgeable and kind Professor. Furthermore, youll gain a very large knowledge-base not only on the EU, but on a lot of political theory (why right-wing parties rise, political bargaining power of the single market, three ideologies of international relations, etc).

Absolutely! If you're interested in the European Union, I cannot think of a better course at Yale. Also, would definitely recommend you spend some time talking to Professor Cameron in office hours because he's very knowledgeable and a super nice professor!

I would recommend this course, but only if the student had a real interest in the EU. I would definitely recommend having some background knowledge, as it allows one to contextualize the topics discussed in the readings.

When I took this class, we had to write a research prospectus at the end of the semester instead of a long research paper. Given that, the course had a pretty low workload, which was great. Seminar was enjoyable and Professor Cameron is a very nice and very knowledgeable guy.

If you are interested in the European Union and love reading a new book every week and are the type to heavily participate in discussion then yes. If you do not think you can commit to the reading load and are generally shy in seminars, then no.
Yes if you are interested in the content.
